qas.question: What permanent structure formed on Antarctica?
The lift of which mountain range in Europe was the result of the African plate moving north into the Eurasian?
During what period was there a land bridge joining Europe and North America?
In the Oligocene period South America broke free from what other continent?
Which current resulted in the cooling of Antarctica?
What semi-perminant feature developed in Antarctica?
What plate was pushing south creating the Alps?
What incursion marked the end of Oligocene?

plausible_answers.text: South America was finally detached from Antarctica

qas.question: What slowed down the Antarctic Circumpolar Current?

context: Antarctica continued to become more isolated and finally developed a permanent <a0_0><b5_0>ice cap<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Mountain building in western <b6_0>North America<b6_0/> continued, and <a1_0>the Alps<a1_0/> started to rise in Europe as the <b7_0>African plate<b7_0/> continued to push north into the Eurasian plate, isolating the remnants of Tethys Sea. A brief <b8_0>marine<b8_0/> incursion marks the early Oligocene in Europe. There appears to have been a land bridge in the early <a2_0>Oligocene<a2_0/> between North America and Europe since the faunas of the two regions are very similar. During the Oligocene, <b9_0>South America was finally detached from <a3_0>Antarctica<b9_0/><a3_0/> and drifted north toward North America. It also allowed <a4_0>the Antarctic Circumpolar Current<a4_0/> to flow, rapidly cooling the continent.
